webTitle: Observer archive: on a kibbutz, 26 May 1958

fields.headline: Observer archive: on a kibbutz, 26 May 1958
fields.standfirst:
Photographer Michael Peto visited Israel and his work illustrated an article by Nora Beloff on the young State’s growing pains.

Buy your exclusive print here
fields.trailText: Photographer Michael Peto visited Israel and his work illustrated an article by Nora Beloff on the young State’s growing pains.
fields.body:
If you are lucky enough to visit the “Promised Land” in this tenth anniversary year, you must not expect to be cosseted.

The excellent English-language tourist guide to Israel is prefaced with the statement from the Torah (the Jewish book of rules): “Whoever walks four cubits on the land of Israel is assured of a place in the world to come.” It wouldn’t do also to expect quick-service lunches or taps that don’t drip.

But a chastened visitor will very soon appreciate the two greatest glories of Israel, the sunshine, and the pervasive sense of purpose.

The optimism of the Israelis, their capacity to dance and be merry without alcoholic stimulus, must certainly have something to do with the sun. Almost every Jewish family arriving in Israel brings in its baggage the memory of personal tragedies. Yet in the three weeks I was there I saw no signs of resentment or self-pity. It is as if the sun has cauterised their grief.

The purposefulness of the Israelis springs from “the in-gathering of the exiles.” The country is in fact constitutionally bound to remain permanently open for any Jews who want to come.

For the Israelis this immigration is the beginning and the end. Other children play at cowboys; Israeli children re-enact the heroism of the men who organised illegal immigration. In this cause terrorism itself was admired. I hear that a museum will shortly be opened in Jerusalem, in the former prison, showing the death cells, gallows and whips allegedly used by the British against the culprits, and their last letters to their families.

Pitiful Ruins

The Israelis are so proud of having welcomed almost a million exiles since their State was formed that they have little pity to spare for the Palestine Arab refugees unable to seek similar hospitality from their own co-religionaries in the neighbouring Muslim countries. The Jews no longer notice the pitiful ruins of deserted Arab villages which scar their country from end to end.

Out of such ruins high up in the northern Galilee a young rabbi from Tunis has built a school for the neighbouring villagers. He and his three aides are teaching the Bible, the three R’s, elementary science and farming to seventy children from surrounding immigrant settlements.

We were invited to share their lunch (vegetable soup, beans, grated carrots and sugary buns). The rabbi predicted the persecution of the Jews would spread and ultimately they would all return to Israel. “Where would you put them?” I asked. He laughed. “One can always squeeze up to make room for the family,” he said. “I am a Believer. I don’t doubt that God will redeem his promise to the Jews and give us all the land up to the Iraqi frontier.”

Other Israelis nearer the seat of power know there can be no further territorial expansion. The fixed aim of Israeli foreign policy is in fact to get existing frontiers internationally guaranteed. To them, the danger seems not too many immigrants but too few: the flow has dropped from 75,000 last year to a current annual rate of 30,000.

Of the two principal remaining reserves, nobody expects many of the five million Jews in the United States to come. The trickle of refugees who have escaped from Russia claim that some half of the three million Jews still there would come if they could, but no Israeli seriously supposes the Russians would agree to put the popularity of their regime to so damaging a test. Outnumbered by the increasingly united surrounding Arab countries by twenty to one, the Israelis regard their immigrants as a precious contribution to defence. The target for the next ten years is to raise the population from two millions to three.

New Hospitals

But the military value of the immigrants is accessory. When the Moroccan Government allowed out batches of tens of thousands of Jews on condition that the local authorities could select the emigrants the Israelis unhesitatingly agreed. Ships were filled with cripples, incurable invalids, lunatics and the very aged. Precious funds and materials were diverted into building hospitals, asylums and rest homes. The new arrivals were helpless but sacrosanct.

Immigration is half paid for by foreign money, but the hard work in settlement and education is a purely Israeli contribution. Most teachers, doctors, welfare officers, are putting in twelve or fifteen voluntary hours of overtime a week.

They don’t have an easy time. A young medical graduate sent to examine health conditions in a rabbinical school in Tel Aviv found lice in the children’s hair. She ordered them to have their heads shaved immediately, and was told that this was out of the question for the next three weeks as it would be sinful to have their hair or nails cut during the six weeks annual mourning period for the great rabbi Shimon ben Yohai. Again, teachers have recently discovered that it is not enough to have different textbooks for young people of different origin. You must also learn to tell different fairy stories. Little Yemenites and Indians, it seems, do not respond to stories about Riding Hoods and glass slippers.

Dividing Forces

There are many forces dividing Israel apart from the diversities of language, habit and behaviour. The political and party system is almost as bad as in France. The strife between Church and State, the intolerance of the religious fanatics and the startling irreverence of their lay critics (I saw a skit at a Tel Aviv night club which would have been too irreligious to be permitted in London) would make Don Camillo’s village a haven of concord. But the differences are all sunk beneath the collective pressure and hard work of settling immigrants and giving homes, hope and happiness to hundreds of thousands of people for whom no one else would have cared. It is an inspiring sight.

Room for the Family by Nora Beloff was published on page nine of the Observer on 1 June 1958.
